title: Apocalypse Now
blurb: A U.S. Army officer (Martin Sheen) serving in Vietname is tasked with assassinating a renegade Special Forces Colonel who sees himself as a god (Marlon Brando).
trivia: Martin Sheen was actually drunk during the early hotel room scene where he actually cut his hand. He even reportedly tried to attack director Francis Ford Coppola

Coppola decided to frame Marlon Brando in shadow in many scenes to hide the extremely overweight actor
Based on the 1899 novel 'Heart of Darkness' where a captain journeys through the Congo River, obsessed with an ivory trader, Kurtz
While set during the Vietnam War, the film was actually shot in the Phillippines
review_text:
Francis Ford Coppola’s 1979 epic war film ‘Apocalypse Now’ is one of the greatest movies I’ve seen. I personally rank it in my ‘top five films’ for a number of reasons.An adaptation of the 19th century novella ‘Heart of Darkness’ by Joseph Conrad, Coppola’s screenplay and adaptation is a mesmerising, surreal and terrifying exploration of the Vietnam War. From the very first scene, an unnerving sense of freedom from the fear of death fuels a sombre, desperate and tribal tone that resonates throughout the film as Martin Sheen’s Captain Willard journeys through Nung River in order to find and assassinate a rogue, PTSD inflicted and now morally destitute 'Colonel Kurtz’ (Marlon Brando), who has taken up a remote, isolated tribal island for himself as chief. The production of this film underwent troubles that’d make my alcohol-driven benders look unproblematic, most notably, the failing health and ego of Marlon Brando and Martin Sheen’s heart attack (as well as Dennis Hopper introducing a fourteen year old Laurence Fishburne to heroin).
A large reason why I enjoy the film so much despite its dark subject matter is its’ candid, almost cinema verité style of direction, accompanied by the terrifying, psychedelic score pair for a horrifyingly surreal experience that exerts a tonne of emotional, political and philosophical depth. Coppola challenges the authority and philosophical ideologies held by Kurtz and juxtaposes them with Willard’s deeply flawed yet unjaded leadership. In a sense, Willard understands Kurtz descent into madness as he has similar experiences because of the Vietnam War, but has the awareness to and mental stability to understand why these ideologues are terrifying.
Martin Sheen and Marlon Brando (despite his continued absence and reluctance to co-operate on set) seemed to tap into an extremely dark emotional place for their respective performances. Sheen’s particular insistence to actually be drunk during the beginning hotel scene seemed to be him working through some real life demons. Brando’s visible weight gain and Coppola’s subsequent decisions to mostly frame him away from light seeped into his traumatised, yet brutal performance as Kurtz. Dennis Hopper did so many drugs on set he was probably going through some shit too, I mean it certainly seemed like it onscreen.
My favourite scene in the film is when Willard’s team make their way to Do Lung Bridge where they find what appears to be hell on earth. Explosions echo and both friendly and enemy soldiers run madly firing their rifles in the dead of the night. All you see is explosions and all you hear is the wild, terrified screams of young American and Vietnamese men as they psychotically yell obscenities at each other through the gunfire.
This film can be emotionally taxing as its horror elements and mostly authentic depiction of the Vietnam War provide unsettling context to the characterisations, however I find this portrayal of men at the end of their ropes relenting to their inner darkness both despicable and fascinating. The art direction and anamorphic quality similar contribute to this harrowing film.

review_text:
Terry Gilliam’s 1985 science fiction film ‘Brazil’ is an entertaining dystopic sci-fi film that utilises a relatively unknown cast (with the exception of a mysterious character ‘Archibald Tuttle’ played by Robert De Niro) to depict a society that is overly reliant on underpowered and poorly constructed machines. The satire of bureaucracy, surveillance and state-capitalism on display in this film is intentionally exaggerated and absurd to the point of unbelievable.
It’s this absurdist take on dystopic sci-fi that creates a whimsical, hazy, fantasy inspired environment that often veers into surreal. I personally find the atmospheric qualities and world-building in this film to be its highlight and main appeal. I’ve always found dystopic societies intriguing in fiction, especially police-states that border on fascism. This is because I like to find little tid-bits in the real world that remind me of fascism in fiction so that I can point out how ‘DYSTOPIC’ society is and how close we are to ‘ULTIMATE COLLAPSE’ because of the right-wing maniacs (but mostly to make myself feel smug and superior over others).
I also find the 1980s style costume, sets and lighting to be classic eighties Hollywood B-movie so that’s cool. Gilliam’s direction is good but nothing spectacular, although very stylized. In terms of narrative, it’s pretty standard and mediocre but I feel it could’ve been more interesting given the bizarre concept.

review_text:
Satoshi Kon directs this animated psychological thriller from Japan. This is not a Studio Ghibli film. ‘Perfect Blue’ follows ‘Mima’, a member of a successful J-Pop group called ‘CHAM!’ Being a young, ambitious woman in Japan, she obviously eventually feels like leaving the group in order to increase her reputation and appeal to older, mature audiences. Becoming a full-time actress, she gains a stalker and associates of hers begin to show up murdered. Her journey through this experience and development as a person is the central focus of the film, as she begins to lose psychological control of reality.
The film highlights fandom and the obsessions that come out of it, as well as the role of young women in the Japanese entertainment industry. The film plays heavily on the male gaze – with plenty of nudity to express the female form as the subject of entertainment, both sexually and non-sexually. That being said, I feel the film falls into a similar trap as ‘Ghost in the Shell’ where female perspectives have been mostly curated and written by males; providing a less insightful exploration of Mima’s psyche. The themes of sexual exploitation within the entertainment industry might’ve been more impactful if more understood from a non-male perspective.
That said, this film is still an entertaining 80 minutes and as engaging as any psychological thriller I’ve seen.

title: Solaris
blurb: A psychologist (Donatas Banionis) is sent to a station orbiting a distant planet in order to discover what has caused the crew to go insane.

review_text:
The opening scenes of this film depict the natural and green landscapes of Earth as we take in a calming and introspective atmosphere. The beauty of the green brush strokes sporadically covered by a ghostly fog is the perfect way of introducing us to the protagonist, Kris Kelvin. If there’s anything to take from this nearly three-hour long feature, it’s how beautifully shot it is. Cinematographer Vadim Yusov encapsulates Tarkovsky’s vision through purposeful foreground and background framing and lengthy long-shots to accentuate the silence and thoughtful atmosphere.
This film if often compared to the innovative ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ that was released three years earlier. While both films feature space-settings, eerie and surreal atmospheres and artistic composition, they diverge in plot and narrative structure. ‘2001’ is more literal in its expression of fear through artificial intelligence and its’ supposed sentience while ‘Solaris’ takes a horror-mystery approach.
Psychologist Kris Kelvin is sent on an interstellar journey to study the oceanic planet ‘Solaris’. Odd events occur on the space-station, and this is the core of the story where Kelvin must attempt to decipher the cause of crew disappearances while fighting hallucinations of his late wife, Hari.
The plot is fairly slow moving and sentimental, with little action occurring throughout. However, this allows more time for audiences to explore the thematic stylings and atmospheric qualities. I’d watch this film again on a slow, reflective Sunday afternoon to distract myself from the feeling of impending doom. Nonetheless, Soviet art films have a way of depicting the unsettling despair of life to make you feel a lot more lucky.

review_text:
Ingmar Bergman’s 1966 film ‘Persona’ opens with an unsettling montage intended to transport the viewer into a surreal and unnerving frame of mind. The experimental, black-and-white film is like nothing I’ve seen before (maybe I’m showing my age). The longing, meditative shots accentuate the therapeutic environment.
There’s a lot to be said about this film, from its’ themes of identity and sexuality that were certainly innovative for the 1960s, to its’ disjointed narrative structure. The insertion of real-world footage, such as the immolation of a Buddhist and lamb slaughter can provide frightening undertones to the concept of mental health and psychological deterioration. The film’s short 84 minute length allow enough space for the narrative to expand and detail it’s thematic punches with perfect execution.
While elements of misogyny and sexual discrimination are heavily apparent (being a product of a white male in the 1960s), the depiction of the two women offer insight into the gender identities of an actress and a nurse from the time period.
In the end, the development of the relationship between the two women is intriguing to watch unfold as their identities seem to merge and become symbiotic. As one of Bergman’s most influential films (as well as ‘The Seventh Seal’), I can see the reason for its continued influence on world cinema – is pretty good movie mang.

Paul Thomas Anderson’s 2002 romantic-comedy ‘Punch-Drunk Love’ is a pivot from the usual pretentious art films I’ve listed thus far. Adam Sandler’s performance shows his range in dramatic roles as his socially awkward ‘Barry’ attempts to find love in Emily Watson’s ‘Lena’.
Unfortunately, Barry has a perverted mishap with a scam phone-sex line and so obviously, hilarity ensues as he attempts to hide this from his romantic interest. Kiefer Sutherland’s personal hacker-man, “Chloe” from ‘24’ makes an appearance as Barry’s sister who likes to violently push him into social situations.
Anderson’s direction is excellent as the fluid camera movements create a frantic, anxious pace that provides the film with both a sense of rhythm and claustrophobia. In this sense, Anderson perfectly executes the creation of ‘atmosphere’ and immersion.
The ensemble cast all perform beyond their best and deliver dialogue with a vivid feel of chemistry. The narrative flow and dialogue make the hour and a half runtime pass by in an instant. While the narrative starts out strong, I personally feel it fizzles out towards the end and improvements could have been made in this department.
However, all things considered, this is one of my favourite films in the list because of its artistic use of colour, framing, blocking, dialogue and deadpan humour. An excellent Sandler classic, bruh.

title: Three Colours: Red

review_text:
I’d recently watched this film and found it intriguing as a concept, hence my decision to add it to the blog. French cinema has never appealed to me, however I’ve found director Krzysztof Kieslowski’s works appealing the past. I’ve seen a mini-series from 1989 called ‘Dekalog’ by Kieslowski and found it bold in its interpretation and depiction of the ten commandments. While I found it fairly hyperbolic, the series demonstrated the intriguing mental state and attitude of Polish culture. This Soviet nihilism reliant on character relationships and storytelling through dialogue – sprinkled with humble humour made his perspective on direction interesting enough for me to add his most critically acclaimed film to my list. This is obviously – “Three Colors: Red”.
The final in a trilogy titled ‘Blue’, ‘White’ and ‘Red’ (after the French flag - which the film borrows French Revolution themes from), ‘Three Colors: Red’ follows Irene Jacob’s ‘Valentine’ as she studies and works as a part-time model in Geneva. Running over a dog in the street, she locates the owner and finds that he is spying on his neighbours – who happen to be extremely wealthy and influential. His status as former detective and Valentine’s growing maturity make for a platonic relationship that is multi-dimensional in emotional depth and eventually symbiotic (to an extent).
At times, the film can be a bit too ‘on-the-nose’ in executing its thematic elements (the golden rule is to ‘show and not tell after all’, however much of this is necessary exposition and context. I’m just saying, maybe he could have been a little more subtle about it but what do I know – I’m not one of the worlds’ most admired cinematic marvels.
One of the most interesting themes of this film is how everyone is ‘interconnected’ in that every person has the ability to be intwined with another person’s life so easily, and often at unprecedented coincidence. Our personal experiences, actions and lifestyles have the ability to affect others without notice and within and instance – especially on a planet where you can send a picture of your genitals halfway across the world and receive a disgusted emoji reply within the span of several seconds. 
While this film’s general tone and narrative structure were personally insignificant (I couldn’t give a fuck less about French people problems) I can still greatly appreciate the character development through Valentine’s various personal connections and (at times) difficult experiences (such as having to reject the sexual advances of a creepy photographer colleague). The red highlights and overall warm colour palette create an exotic, yet realistic and engaging atmosphere that perfectly accentuate the narrative development. I feel Kieslowski deserves all the praise for his direction for this film and cannot discount it’s artistic and cinematic merit, regardless of how much of a shit I give about its’ narrative elements.

Mimi Woods’ stilted and awkward performance as the cyborg Major Kusanagi is however, excellent. She perfectly portrays the Major as a voided, justice-bent moral cyborg.
While I enjoyed the nostalgia of old-school Japanese animation, the lower framerate as well as jagged animation felt slightly cheap for a feature-length film. Even older films like ‘Akira’ have more fluid and grand animation.
While I understand the film’s intention to develop themes of gender and sexuality through Kusanagi’s appearance in a world where reproduction is non-sexual and mechanical, I still found Kusanagi’s voluptuous figure extreme and formed towards the male-gaze. I don’t mean to say I’m a prude, I just feel it becomes crystal clear this film was made by men when every close-up of Kusanagi focuses on her figure and every other scene features gunshots louder than my pained squeals when I urinate every morning.
I don’t know man this movie kind of sucked and that’s pretty disappointing, hence this short and HALF-ASSED review.

title: Children of Men
blurb: In 2027, in a chaotic world in which women have become somehow infertile, a former activist (Clive Owen) agrees to transport a miraculously pregnant woman (Clare-Hope Ashitey) to a sanctuary at sea.
trivia: The infertility crisis in this film is caused by all women being infertile while in the novel it's caused by men no longer producing sperm

review_text:
The first thing about this film is that they call refugees ‘Fugees’ as if they’re some critically acclaimed hip hop group from the nineties. If you can get past that, the movie is immersive, captivating and anxiety-inducing.
If you’ve played the 2013 video game ‘The Last of Us’, the plot will feel familiar where an elder male who’s clearly ‘too old for this shit’ escorts a young lady thought to be the only hope in an apocalyptic world through a brutal, tribalist society.
Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey) is a pregnant woman (formally a prostitute) in a world where a child has not been born in over 18 years. While the reason for this global infertility crisis is unexplained, the context is enough to build a fully-detailed and realistic world. The United Kingdom is the lone standing city and has become a police-state that detains and executes illegal immigrants / refugees fleeing other collapsed countries. The state of despair across the country is especially apparent when Theo and Kee transport throughout the country in search of a safe place for Kee to deliver and raise her baby. The poverty on display is reminiscent of the Balkan and Iraq wars of the late 20th to early 21st centuries. Innocent civilians are displaced and forced to shelter in high density blocks that are often the target of military strikes or raids due to ‘terrorist activity’.
Stylistically, Cuaron directs this film with perfect execution. His trademark long-tracking-shots allow a sense of tension and immersion to build in especially scary scenes. Cuaron and cinematographer Lubezki often paint the foreground with the ragged, tired demeanours of the core characters while pumping the background with exposition and an astounding amount of context. I especially love the use of long-tracking shots because I feel they tremendously add to the sense of fear and unsettling dread throughout the film; they’re peppered throughout and used a perfect amount.
The thematic references to the Holocaust where Nazi slogans are scrawled across brick walls and Abu Ghraib prison – featuring hooded prisoners being tortured and forced into inhumane conditions provide a grim undertone that fuels an intensely brutal and realistic depiction of a possible future. Cuaron’s decision to film this ‘cinema-verite’ (documentary style) expands this unsettling feeling whenever the group busses past a group of caged refugees or drives past a seemingly endless amount of zombie-like agitators. A particular scene on a bus towards the Bexhill-on-Sea prison camp is executed perfectly as the flow slowly depicts an escalating amount of inhumane practice upon prisoners. You begin to feel unsettled as your fears slowly become confirmed and realise you’re heading into an Auschwitz-Warsaw-Ghetto hybrid.
I also felt like shouting ‘PICK UP A FUCKING GUN’ at Theo the entire film and was enthralled and anxious the entire latter half of the film – which felt like it flew by in a second.
Aside from a few stilted acting performances (I’m thinking the younger, slightly less experiences actors), this film is a CERTIFIED MUST WATCH.

review_text:
Kevin Spacey is really good at portraying creepy characters, I wonder why that is? His Lester Burnham is a depressed, middle-aged man-child that seeks “excitement” and sexual thrill in an underaged friend of his daughters’. His life within American suburbia consists of an equally depressed wife and cliché teenaged daughter (struggling with the usual teenage girl issues). While seemingly having a functioning, typical suburban lifestyle, Lester’s contempt for his life seems to be self-inflicted as he wallows in self-victimhood and loathing. I found him deeply unlikeable due to his toxic attitude towards his family, creeping on his teenage daughters’ friend, taking his clearly overworked wife for granted and just overall – failing to appear as a stable role model and husband.
We’re never made aware of how he came to be this way, and are to assume that (as eloquently put by Thora Birchs’ Janie) he’s a complete loser. Throughout the course of the film, Lester begins to stop caring about anything – detaching from the rote, boring lifestyle of a working, suburban father. This is sparked by a desire to fuck his daughter’s underaged friend – as he works out, starts smoking cannabis (sourced by a neighbour’s son) and emphatically quits his white collar sales job for burger flipping.I feel that while Lester’s storyline as he becomes a less self-aware, yet positive and  more positive and secure with himself is the core line of the film, his tertiary and surrounding interactions and relationships with characters are the more telling and introspective as satire on late 1990s / early 2000s American suburbia. Lester’s lack of emotional intelligence when dealing with his wife and daughter are a scathing depiction of the role of men in a modern world. This is further explored with Ricky’s father and his own repressed homosexuality, as well as how this combination of the historical patriarchal framework and modern understanding of masculinity collides in destructive ways.
As a perspective on the dark underbelly of boring suburbia, I feel the film fantastically fills a clean, monotonous, yet visually striking atmosphere while using colourful cinematography (framing in particular) to accentuate critical themes of class and sexual repression. There’s a lot to be said about this film aside from the creepy (but realistic in many ways) relationship between Angela (Jane’s friend) and Lester. I haven’t written enough on Lester’s wife, Carolyn, or their daughter, as well as Allison Janney’s character because they’re all very interesting in their own ways – but there’s like thirty more films to watch.

review_text:
Michael Mann’s feature film directorial debut is straight out of the 1980s. With a score provided by electronic / new age band ‘Tangerine Dream’, this heist film follows an ex-convict, Frank (James Caan) as he attempts to pull off one last job worth millions before quitting the game.
Personally, I found Frank inherently unlikeable despite his sympathetic backstory involving poverty, prison and survival. His experiences in prison lead him to an unfearful, resilient mentality that gave no regard for his personal wellbeing. It is through this mentality that Frank believed he survived the brutality and oppression of prison life. While this view is understandable, Frank seemingly appears to be unable to learn to evolve his views as the films progresses. His character does not change as he seems insistent on working his way; for himself and family only. This proves challenging as he soon has things to lose and insists on his lone-wolf, abrasive ways.
I found myself actively rooting against Frank as he seemed a product of his times – a greedy, misogynistic and status-hungry white male with little self-awareness. His relationship with Jessie (Tuesday Weld) seems increasingly transactional and simply because having a wife and family are simply part of his life plan. The simplicity of his feelings portray a shallow and undeserving individual which reminds me of the aggressive behaviour of Tony Montana without the immigrant hunger or coke-addled paranoia. While Tony was similarly unlikeable, the film ‘Scarface’ still showed the negative impact of Tony’s actions throughout the film, whether it’s the breakdown of his relationship with his family or downfall of his empire.
In comparison, Frank’s character is more like Charles Bronson in ‘Death Wish’ – an insecure and hypermasculine male with no regard for anyone else’s conundrums. They live completely inside their own head. While this mentality is justified through Frank’s imprisonment, this still provides very little space for emotional development. Frank continuously is arrogant and unable to learn. Leo (Robert Prosky) provides Frank with all he could possibly want from life and more; while Frank shows very little appreciation for the depths of Leo’s actions.
The film then rewards Frank for his behaviour as he murders all of his ex-partners in order to escape the criminal heat on him. Willie Nelson’s character is severely undeveloped and his death provides little motivation for Frank to continue the heist (which he was seemingly doing to get his buddy out of jail before he dies of heart disease. Tuesday Weld’s character ‘Jessie’ is similarly underdeveloped as she serves only as a prop for Frank’s character to marry and nurture his adopted child.
However, the score (created by Tangerine Dream) is outstanding as the light synthesizers build tension during the heist and shootout scenes. The score is used sparingly as most of the dialogue is backed with silence – which allows the instances the score is used to be far more grand and emphatic in cinematic emotion.
Overall, this film is just a’ight. Good action, poor (or outdated) characterisations but excellent score and realism when it comes to the actual heist scene.

review_text:
Akira Kurosawa’s 1954 classic ‘Seven Samurai’ is about a village that hires a bunch of unemployed samurai to defend themselves from a series of attackers and bandits. This is a long-ass movie and its premise is one of the most influential in cinema history. The core storyline of a troubled community banding a series of mercenaries together to defend them has been referenced and reworked a zillion times in world cinema. Classic video games like ‘Mass Effect 2’ even refer to this story arc with the search for Shephard’s allies in defending Earth and the Citadel.
Samurai films are often seen as the Japanese equivalent to Cowboy westerns – and for good reason. They share many themes such as lone wolves fighting against bandits and thieves in a battle of morality in old-timey civilisations. I’m not sure I have a lot to say about this film that hasn’t already been said in a thousand film classes before. This is a certified classic in terms of overall production – dialogue? Excellent. Cinematography? Ground-breaking for the 1950s. Sound? Nostalgic of the stage-era of cinema. You feel for the peasants as they cry for better crop yields and livelihoods. There are clear-cut moral lines to help you feel for certain characters. It all makes me yearn for a simpler time – when women knew their place and when specific races weren’t allowed in certain restaurants (that’s right, I’m looking at you, Bulldog/Schnauzer cross-breed, you ugly fucking dog).
Nostalgia aside, this is a classic movie that everyone should watch unless you don’t care for old movies or Japanese cinema. Then just watch something new and English-language that rehashes the plot elements from this film, you’ll have the same experience as I did watching this movie and it’ll be a blast. Probably. It’s actually very entertaining once you get invested.
I really didn’t feel like taking notes on this film because it’s nearly four-fucking hours and I’ve seen it already so I just watched it for fun. It was a lot less fun than the first time and made me regret adding this to my film list because it was a SLOG the second time-round.
Honestly if you want to read something in-depth about this movie, go visit the Film department in the Arts sector of your local University – it’ll be the rundown building down several flights of stairs beside the janitor’s closet. You’ll know you’re there when you feel like you’ve just entered Auschwitz.
You know what? Fuck this film for making me spend nearly four hours bored out of my mind, I give it a star and a half out of five because it sucks the second time.

review_text:
Bong Joon-ho’s 2019 Academy Award Best Picture winning film ‘Parasite’ is an entertaining look into the socio-economic dynamics of South Korean society. Personally (which is what you’re here for), I blame this all on hyper-capitalist American influence poisoning South Korean culture with it’s ‘all work, no play, MAKE LOTS OF MONEY’ mantra causing all this damn economic inequality and corporatism. Regardless of your views on economic policy, it’s largely irrelevant because economics only provides context (although great for a thorough watch) for the core narrative – which is the evolving relationship between a seemingly unconnected lower-class group of people and their wealthy employers.
The film is dense with humour, horror elements and tension that carry it through a tightly scripted two hour runtime. The keen intelligence and innovation of the Kim family struggling to maintain employment status for each member through the wealthy Park family is somehow both humorous to watch and anxiety-inducing. Additionally, the constructed sets, costumes and props all add to the distinction of classes between the two families. Bong Joon-ho also uses cinematic framing and direction to expertly guide our eyes and emotions with subtlety and poise. Elements of horror and suspense are also sprinkled throughout to keep a sense of tension and unease that help to build to an unnerving and surprising climax that is well worth the invested time.

review_text:
Based on William Shakespeare’s classic ‘King Lear’, this two and a half hour expedition into medieval Japan is an enthralling, captivating, surreal and picturesque film that rounded out Akira Kurosawa’s career in the perfect way before his passing. It’s also lovely that he colour-codes every son’s kimono (?) so you can easily tell who’s who.
This film is beautifully shot and contrasts well with the rest of Kurosawa’s most influential films – which were mostly black-and-white. This film shows Kurosawa and cinematographer’s Takao Saito, Masaharu Ueda and Asakazu Nakai’s creative and technical talent in crafting vibrant, complex and layered paintings through each frame. As far as epic films go, this may be one of the most visually compelling. You feel completely immersed in in the meticulously curated long-shots and windy landscapes.
As far as narratives go, this is a classic Kurosawa take on a Shakespearean tragedy. That will either entice you or make you fall asleep. Personally, it was in the middle for me. I didn’t fall asleep but I mean, it’s Shakespeare, you know. That being said, the Kurosawa elements in score, Japanese cultural elements and humour are visibly apparent and a large part of the particular charm this film has in differentiating itself from most contemporary Shakespeare adaptations.

title: Rope
blurb: Two men (John Dall & Farley Granger) attempt to prove they committed the perfect crime by hosting a dinner party after strangling their former classmate to death (Dick Hogan).

review_text:
The first thing you should know about this movie is that when the opening credits roll (as they do in many old timey films), the final credit reads ‘DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK’ in a font size about twice the size of my ass (which is pretty fucking huge) – so you know this movie is as pretentious as its’ homophobe director.
I have mixed feelings about this film. On one hand, the story of a couple of college-educated killers attempting to pull off the perfect murder is an interesting tale – particularly as it comes after the end of World War II, where themes of morality and fascism are heavily apparent. A particular conversation early on in the dinner party where Rupert lures fascist opinion from Brandon – ‘advocating for inferior beings to be culled’ strikes discomfort with party guests as Brandon seemingly does not detect the satire in Rupert’s tone. These discussions reference Hitler’s recent atrocities and provide a clear window into Brandon’s psyche. This is juxtaposed with Philip’s tense, scatty demeanour that is clearly affected by his recent actions.
Alfred Hitchcock’s direction follows the suspense with extremely long takes to make the film seem like one long scene which was innovative for the time.
On the other hand, I feel the film squanders all the tension and suspense it builds with the departure of all of the party guests following David’s strange disappearance. Once all the party guests leave, Brandon basks in the glory of a perfectly executed murder and dinner party (likely to provide an alibi for the two). It’s unclear what the departure of the guests is supposed to achieve, as Rupert returns on an unsettling hunch that Brandon and Philip have something to do with David’s disappearance. Claiming to have forgotten his cigarette case and planting it on top of David’s coffin (unbeknownst to Rupert), it seems that this scene would have been more effective and entertaining with the presence of the remaining guests.
Personally, the film feels unfinished due to this – and it’s 80 minute run time – which could have been expanded to portray the other guests’ reactions and feelings towards David’s murder. It feels particularly strange to omit David’s fiancee Janet and parents (all of whom attended the dinner party) from discovering this revelation, especially because these characters provide a lot of personality and depth to their scenes.
The end scene, which depicts Rupert becoming flustered by Brandon’s twisted interpretation of his own words falls flat due to the missing presence of important characters. If they were not essential to this scene, I’m not sure what their purpose in the film was to begin with aside from being discardable emotional props.
All in all, I was excited and enthralled with this film from early to late middle point. The singular setting provided an episodic and familiar tone that could have been exploited for further drama had all the characters stayed where they were. This leads to an extremely underwhelming climax that makes me wish I’d never started watching this film in the first place. What a waste of time.

review_text:
Make no mistake, while labelled a war film – this is without a doubt, one of the most terrifying films I’ve ever witnessed. To be fair, I don’t generally watch horror films so it’s a small sample size but in terms of intensity, this film is up there. A lot of this intensity stems from the events depicted in the film being too real and straight from the memories of the writers / director.
Set in 1943, two Belarusian boys dig up a couple of rifles in order to be able to enter the Soviet partisan forces. Youthful idealism and glorification of war is a foundational theme in this film and we are exposed to this almost instantly. As partisans arrive to one of the boys (Flyora) house, we see the terror in his mother’s eyes as she pleads with the partisans and her son to not participate.
This is both one of my favourite films on account of the sheer emotion and authenticity on display, and one of my least favourite for the exhaustive toll it takes on you watching it. The film felt so genuine and terrifying that the Flyora’s real actor (Aleksei Kravchenko) hair started greying and the boy experienced PTSD. This is a film only to watch if you’re ready for it.

I’ve always found Robert Downey Jr. scummy and that opinion has not changed.
Now that’s out the way, on the positive, Keanu Reeves is great in this as he plays an undercover cop ‘Arctor’ as he attempts to infiltrate a smuggling ring in this adaptation of a classic Philip K. Dick novel. I entered this with high expectations, and was left slightly disappointed in that I feel the script was half-baked in terms of dialogue. Both Reeves and Downey Jr. had cringeworthy lines and played two-dimensional stereotypes (in Reeves case, his typecast role as quiet, introverted detective and Downey Jr as skeevy drug addict – which wasn’t exactly acting) that I feel could’ve been better expanded on. Nonetheless, the rotoscope animation is fascinating and worth the watch if you’re into animation. While I feel the animation can feel outdated and cheap at times, it’s still interesting enough because it stands out from most other films in this genre.
I’m surprised by how under-the-radar this film seemed to be when it came out, but I suppose both Keanu Reeves and Robert Downey Jr. are hotter assets now than they were a decade and a half ago.

review_text:
When I first watched this movie, I liked it. Second time around and about five years of incompetent life experiences later, I fucking hate this movie. I guess somewhere in the past five years I became disinterested in Lynchian portrayals of 1950s suburbia with obedient damsels and pale-skinned femme-fatale mysteries. I mean seriously, the whole reason the dude gets into the gigantic mess he does (spoiler) is because he sneaks into a woman’s apartment to fucking perve on her. Like dude seriously? Then he starts nailing this clearly mentally unstable, tortured woman and it’s like “bruh…”
That’s not even as bad as it gets. He starts seeing a HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR WHO’S ALREADY DATING SOME JOCK. Man does not care. Then he has the fucking gall to act all surprised when SURPRISE, the mentally unstable woman starts needing him and wanders naked and delirious to his house while he has the senior over talking shit like ‘he nutted in me and you’re basic’ – this movie’s more “the adventures of dumbass white boy” than it is surreal mystery.
Where the film does shine is in its exploration of sexual sadomasochism and dreamlike mise-en-scene. The performances of Dennis Hopper and his criminal associates while heavily over the top, are inspiring in their depictions as disgusting demons of the night. When this movie veers into surrealism, such as the vivid scene at Ben’s where multiple actions and behaviours occur simultaneously with the fluidity and unexpected execution of a stage performance, it veers like that country-redneck from Tokyo Drift.
This was still a pretty disappointing viewing, I probably wouldn’t watch it again.

review_text:
Dude so first and foremost, I hate Australia and cannot for the LIFE OF ME stand the Australian accent. That being said, George Miller is one talented dude. Following the events of the first Mad Max, famous anti-semite Mel Gibson speeds through the Australian wasteland as a lone merc accompanied by a cattle dog. The post-apocalyptic Australian desert is sparsely populated by gangs, bandits and as Max discovers, a surviving township / civilisation.
I toughed out my extreme dislike for Australia and their residents to watch this movie and although I feel I’ve betrayed my morals, it resulted in a satisfying and thrilling journey through what I assume will be Australia in five to ten years (depending on whether or not they keep electing Scott Morrison).
Oil is the main commodity of society following total global collapse as the supply of oil is practically depleted. The rabid wasteland is infested with surviving marauders that Max must ultimately evade to escort the settlers of the township Far North (apparently the Sunshine Coast in Queensland). This journey and development of Max as a gritty, lone wolf merc to gritty, lone wolf merc with some heart isn’t exactly riveting, but the circumstances of the world and stakes at hand are compelling enough to accentuate the action to produce a fantastic, easy-watch film.

review_text:
I’ll admit I had a difficult time trying to tell all these Aryan whites in their uniforms apart - but mostly got a handle on it through their surnames.
Additionally, Netflix only had the director’s cut version and I couldn’t be fucked pirating the theatrical release – which led me to sleeping through most of this film because it was so fucking long and I’m not sure I really gave a shit. I PROMISE THIS IS THE ONLY MOVIE I DID SO.
Probably doesn’t help this was the first film I watched on this review-spree, really set the tone for the rest of the reviews.
But from what I gather through Wikipedia and random episodic memories of the viewing, the film focused on the perspective of a German U-Boat crew in the midst of the Second World War. This was intriguing to me because of the lack of Nazi perspectives in my knowledge-base, but I soon grew to realise this was a mostly West-German (AMERICA) production that held strong anti-Nazi views. I mean, this is ideal but in terms of experiencing and trying to fully understand the mindset of a racist-ass Nazi crew, I was certainly disappointed. There was character development for sure, I recall the construction of the Lieutenant journalist to be particularly basic in his ‘fish-out-the-water’ soldier story but to be fair, I can’t honestly say shit because I was errantly snoozing the whole time.
While I was enthused in the film (the first hour or so), I found the inclusion of a battle-hardened older veteran protagonist far too admirable for a Nazi, you know what I mean? It helped that he (along with several other introduced elders) expressed an alienation and a sense of bitter resentment towards the Fuhrer and seemed broken enough to illicit such feeling.
After falling asleep and missing the actual film, I decided to read several reviews (as well as the plot) on Wikipedia and saw that the original author of the book the film is based on felt it was over-dramatised and many actors over-acted. When viewed from that perspective, the Hollywood score, extreme close ups on facial emotions and purposely cut frames become obvious in their west German funding influence. That being said, who doesn’t enjoy a little West German influence in their day-to-day life (praise President Ronald Reagan).
Overall I’ll most likely rewatch the director’s cut because I enjoyed the tense, claustrophobic environment of the boat. Similarly, we were exposed to a seemingly straight-laced German whose brain I’d actually like to pick. I also watched this film about three hours before I found out there was a COVID-19 outbreak in Auckland so that may have fragmented my memory somewhat.
I give this film 2.5 stars out of 5 – THAT’S RIGHT I FEEL LIKE IF A MOVIE LEADS ME TO SLEEP IT’S NOT WORTHY OF A DECENT RATING.
